newsitem.title: CHINA: HK's new govt caught between labour and industry.
newsitem.headline: HK's new govt caught between labour and industry.

text.p: Hong Kong's new government said it would introduce legislation on Wednesday to suspend pre-handover labour laws boosting workers' rights, but trade unions said they would continue fighting against a "tycoon dictatorship".

The government, led by Beijing-backed chief executive Tung Chee-hwa, announced on Tuesday that the laws adopted by the colonial legislature just days before China dissolved it would need a "proper and thorough scrutiny of the implications".

The laws boosting union strength have aligned the unelected government, which took over on July 1 after China regained sovereignty over Hong Kong from Britain, with powerful industrialists in a struggle against labour groups.
Hong Kong's industry-backed Liberal Party says the laws will damage the economy.
James Tien, a member of the Provisional Legislature and also a clothing and property magnate, told the South China Morning Post:
"If we don't abolish them quickly, it will not only undermine investors' confidence in Hong Kong, it will also ruin the harmonious employer-employee relationship."

But Lee Cheuk-yan, general secretary of the Hong Kong Confederation of Trade Unions (CTU), told Reuters: "Even if they repeal the law, we can still try to use our industrial strength for collective bargaining, but the law would have given us a very much established channel."
He said industrial tycoons dominated the new Executive Council and Provisional Legislature, where their influence was untempered by elected lawmakers. Elections are due to be held next May.
"If (the Provisional Legislature) does more than the minimum, it would give a very clear message, it would be a patronage of tycoons and they don't care about the rule of law."
One of the last-minute laws gives unions the right to use collective bargaining in negotiating workers' pay packages.
"It's a very basic right enshrined in the International Labour Convention and it's a basic right enjoyed by our competitors in Asia and elsewhere," said Lee.
He began a five-day hunger strike in protest against the government's proposal to suspend the labour laws, local radio reported late on Tuesday.
Analysts have repeatedly warned that Hong Kong's competitiveness is already threatened by its high labour costs and soaring property prices which slash profit margins.
But some say that greater union bargaining power, which would almost certainly drive up wages, would upset employers' but may not be a total disaster.

"(The laws) shift more negotiating power to labour, so employers have less negotiating power, it's understandable they're not overly happy about the provisions of the law," said Michael Martin, assistant chief economist with the Hong Kong Trade Development Council,
"On the other hand, if the average Hong Kong worker is receiving a higher income, it means they have a higher disposable income and can consume more, and stimulate the economy," he said.

Martin said other nations around the world had identified collective bargaining as a fundamental workers' right and there was a push for members of the World Trade Organisation (WTO) to support it. Chinese-ruled Hong Kong is a WTO member, and negotiations are under way for the admission of China proper.
